title: Dynamics of an object in a resistive medium

content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. In an experiment, students used video analysis to track the motion of an object falling vertically through a fluid in a glass cylinder. The object of <math alttext="m equals 12 grams " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is released from rest at the top of the column of fluid, as shown above. The data for the speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the falling object as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are graphed on the grid below. The dashed curve represents the best fit chosen by the students for these data. (a) i. Does the speed of the object increase, decrease, or remain the same? Increase Decrease Remain the same

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. In an experiment, students used video analysis to track the motion of an object falling vertically through a fluid in a glass cylinder. The object of <math alttext="m equals 12 grams " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is released from rest at the top of the column of fluid, as shown above. The data for the speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the falling object as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are graphed on the grid below. The dashed curve represents the best fit chosen by the students for these data. (a) i. Does the speed of the object increase, decrease, or remain the same? Increase Decrease Remain the same
ii. In a brief statement, describe the direction of the object’s acceleration and how the magnitude of this acceleration changed as the object fell.

iii. Using the graph, calculate an approximate value for the magnitude of the acceleration of the object at <math alttext="t equals 0.20 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The students use the equation <math alttext="V equals A, times, open parenthesis 1 minus e raised to the negative B t power, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to model the speed of the falling object and find the best fit coefficients to be <math alttext="A, equals 1.18 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B equals 5 per second " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mrow><mtext> s</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> . (b) Use the above equation to: i. Derive an expression for the magnitude of the vertical displacement <math alttext="y of t " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of the falling object as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

ii. Derive an expression for the magnitude of the net force <math alttext="F of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> exerted on the object as it falls through the fluid as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The students repeat the experiment with a taller glass cylinder that is filled with the same fluid. The cylinder is tall enough so that the object reaches a constant speed. (c) i. Determine the constant speed of the object. Justify your answer.
ii. Determine the force exerted by the fluid on the object at this time. Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
